FIFA's evident double standards have raised significant concerns. On one hand, they enthusiastically welcome Qatar as the host of the 2022 World Cup, a nation notorious for its suppression of women's rights. On the other hand, they display rapid condemnation when a simple kiss becomes the subject of scrutiny.

This stark contrast exposes a disconcerting lack of consistency in FIFA's approach. While they choose to overlook the glaring issues of gender oppression in Qatar, they eagerly assume a moral high ground in the case of a minor display of affection.

Such behavior erodes FIFA's credibility and integrity. By failing to address the real and pressing matter of human rights in Qatar, while simultaneously trying to assert moral authority elsewhere, FIFA is exhibiting a form of hypocrisy that cannot be ignored.

In essence, FIFA's actions reveal a disheartening prioritization of convenience over ethics. Their inconsistency stands as a betrayal of their responsibilities and underscores the urgent need for accountability.

There was a similar incident - fully non-consensual - after Spain's win at the 2010 World Cup. It involved Goalkeeper (and captain [?]) Iker Casillas and his then girl-friend - in her day job as a journalist - tasked to get access to him for the first interview after the win. He kind of waved a finger at the question while looking at her with a bedroom level of intensity, pulled her in and left her properly flustered with a raw kiss.
Spain is different but not necessarily in a bad way. My only visit to Spain was a long weekend in Barcelona back in the Noughties. A feature that struck me was the sight of these guys who probably only made 5'5" before breakfast in the morning walking around clubs with the quiet masculine assurance I more readily associated with a heavyweight boxer strolling along the street. That phenomenon gave me insight for the first time how most of Central and South America came to be Spanish speaking: these boys are real men. Men only become 'men' because the women around them nurture them in that way. It is a virtuous circle as well because central to the self-identity of such men is a cherishing of their women which is a precious and priceless thing: like love in a relationship, you only miss it when it has gone but it has gone, it's gone for good.
Spain is in danger of throwing out a very healthy baby with the bathwater here (and lightly-soiled bathwater at that). Spanish culture is Spanish society's greatest resource: despite facing the juggernaut of self-belief allied with high technical skills and physicality that the England womens' team has become over the past couple of years, the thinking people in the UK kind of knew the Spanish girls would win last Sunday. Just like we knew that Spain would win back in 2010. Only a fundamentally healthy national culture is capable of consistently carrying nationals to these heights. That would also contain the clear ability to override self interest and ego with an understanding of the organisation they represent.
